text: Suburban Connecticut, outside of New York City, 1973. The still after a terrible storm. Trees dripping, their branc torn, the air warming just before the break of a new day. train lies dark and motionless, a few flashing yellow emergency lights up front, as a work crew removes debris the track.

Various passengers, huddled uncomfortably, cold, asleep. On Paul Hood, 15-and-a-half, stoner-preppie look, hunched in his seat under the faint emergency exit light. He read his Fantastic Four comic book by the pale light of the emergency exit sign. Suddenly, the lights begin to flicker on and the hum of t train's engines returns. The conductor enters the car, blasting forth in his class nasal voice.
Good morning ladies and gentlemen -- He sounds like a baseball announcer.
(mumbling, ad lib) What ladies?

-- this train originating at New York's Grand Central Station is back in service - next stop will be New Canaan, Connecticut. New Canaan, Connecticut, next stop! He moves on to the next car. The train begins to move. Paul rubs his elbow against the window and looks out into still-dark early morning. He looks back down at his comic book. On the comic book: Reed Richards (also known as Stretch) zapped his young son with a cosmic ray gun to neutralize destructive energy that Annihilus has implanted in him.  The Thing, Medusa, Flame, and Richards' wife Sue Storm lo on, stunned.

head_text.subj: CONTINUED TO BUILD, HE WOULD HAVE

text: Paul looks up again, thinking.

In issue number 141 of The Fantastic Four, published in November 1973, Reed Richards has to use his anti-matter weapon on his own son, who Annihilus has turned into a human atom bomb. His son is the result of Richards' coupling with the earthling Sue Storm, and the problem is that the cosmic rays that infused Richards and the rest of the Fantastic Four on their aborted moon mission have made young Franklin a volatile mixture of matter and anti-matter.
The train moves slowly through a suburban, semi-forested landscape.

And that's what it is to come from a family, if you analyze it closely. Each of them is negative matter for the other ones. And that's what dying is -- dying is when your family, which is in fact your personal negative matter from which you emerge -- it's when the family takes you back, thus hurling you back into negative space... INT. TRAIN. CONT'D. On Paul, as the sun breaks over the horizon. His face glo warmly in the yellow light. He looks down idly at the com book.
So it's a paradox -- the closer you're drawn back in, the further into the void you're thrown.

The train slowly pulls in. The train doors open, and Paul, weary from the long night emerges. He sees his family gathered at the other end of platform -- Ben, 40, a bit worse for wear but still retai traces of his boyish looks; Elena, 37, distant and elegan even in her oversized sweater; and Wendy, 14, a sullen suburban Lolita. He pauses, regarding them. They stand, silent, even dignified, awaiting him.
To establish. A typical New England prep school.

head_text.subj: INT. PAUL AND FRANCIS'S DORM ROOM. MORNING

text: Cramped, a mess, but quaint. Paul shares the room with Francis Davenport IV, a dissolute, smart-ass son of money Paul's alarm clock rings. He slams his hand down on it an jumps out of bed, fully clothed in his rumpled preppie uniform of frayed khakis, loose tie, shirt with one tail untucked in, etc. Across the room, Francis beckons from h desk, as he finishes loading up a four-foot-high bong.
Arise and shine, young Hood.
I hope you changed the water in that bong from last night.

(finishing a hit) The water, as you call it, is a special mixture of amaretto and Ben&Ben blended for just the exact chemical interaction with the last of our precious Thai stick. Paul reluctantly walks over and takes a hit. He coughs, spewing uninhaled smoke.
Waste not Master Hood -- that was $20 for the bag.

(gathering books, papers, almost talking to himself) Man, Francis, you are one drug addled elitist freak, and when the revolution comes I do not want to be lined up with you and shot, 'cause you're fucking ripe for political reeducation, you know, like in the fields.
Paul, cancel your mental appointments, baby. What are you, like still stoned from last night?
(spraying some chloroform mouth spray) I gotta get to English class.
An English class in progress. Paul Hood sits blankly, hardly listening, until he hears teacher call out.
Libbets?

What Dostoyevsky is saying here is that to be a Christian is to choose, because you have to choose of your own choice, but since you can't choose to be good because that would be too rational you have to choose to be bad -- it's existential.
Thank you Libbets, that's a very compelling summary, but -- Paul looks at her, smitten. Marge, Paul's friend, notices look.
As class lets out, Paul accosts Libbets.
Um, Libbets. Hey, Dostoyevsky, I'm also really a fan, and what you were saying, you know, have you ever read The Idiot?
The Idiot?
If you liked Notes from Underground, you'll love The Idiot.
(turning to go) Great, thanks for the tip.
(after her) The Idiot.
Paul walks with Marge.
I'm in love with Libbets Casey.
Yeah, well, you've been in love with like every other girl here, I was wondering when you'd get around to Libbets.
It's beyond mere physical attraction.
That's good, because I don't think Libbets is capable of the sex act.
Truly? Do speak.

My diagnosis is messed in the head. A poor little rich girl -- I mean check out the jeans and fur look. And lend your ears to this brutality. Like her mom and step dad and her step-sisters are going to Switzerland to ski over Thanksgiving break -- and like they didn't invite her!
How do you know this shit?
They did it last year too. It's like traditional or something. They've got this humongoid Park Ave apartment and she just holes up there with a wad of cash.  (beat) Aren't the hugely wealthy sad?
(pause) You think Francis is going to beat me to the punch here?
Since he sleeps with every girl you ever show an interest in, why don't you just keep your Libbets thing a secret from him?
Good thinking Marge.

Paul, Francis and friends enter the dark, crowded room. Various kids are awkwardly dancing to some progressive fm style undanceable rock (Jethro Tull, etc.) Francis hands the tail end of a joint, but Paul waves it away.
No more man. I'm about to drop as it is.
See ya.
Where you going?

Paul, let me enlighten you about something. You and I exist on two opposite sides of a great existential divide, that being your pathetic virginity on the one hand and my astonishing number of sexual conquests on the other. I'm off to get laid. See you.
Flame on, asshole.

And remember, with your erogenous zones lubricated as such with the mighty herb, do not attempt terrestrial contact with members of the opposite sex -- because you drone on like a motherfucker when you're stoned. He waves his fingers toward Paul's eyes, in the classic "stoned" gesture, then wanders off. Paul looks on at the gathering. Marge waves to him from t dance floor.
Paul wanders, stoned, through the party. He sees Libbets across the room. She seems to be surrounded by friends.
Paul has cornered Libbets and is talking over the music. There are just a few people left, most of them making out with each other.

(stoned) -- because I've been reading Kerouac and Ginsberg and those guys were creating beat culture and traveling and sleeping wherever, and, of course, with all kinds of people, but when you read carefully the various contemporary accounts of their lives, and, uh, these guys didn't bathe much, I mean they were really filthy, with like genital crabs, lice, exceptionally strong body odor... Libbets smiles through her yawn.

Paul sits alone on the bench, freezing cold, eating a don Some kids from across the lawn yell good-night to him. INT. DORM ROOM. EVENING. Paul is at his desk. Francis enters, wrapped in a towel, fresh from the shower.
How can you do that man?
Do what?
Sleep all day. I mean, look, it's already getting dark outside, and you're just getting up.
(beat) Um, Libbets Casey.
What?
Aha! I could sense the vibe.
What do you mean?
Am I right or am I right?
Shit. You're not planning --

My man, I speak to you solely as a comrade in arms offering unconditional aid. I've been giving this one a lot of thought, and I believe that the two of you together might just reach that higher ground that -- A knock at the door.
Hood, telephone. Paul rolls off his bed, opens the door.
Don't mess with Libbets. I mean it!
Paul walks to the pay phone at the end of the hall.
Hello?
It's a modern (shag carpet, geometric-patterned wallpaper etc.) suburban house. Ben Hood talks on the phone, a drink in his hand.
Paul? In the background, we can see Wendy watching Richard Nixo TV.
Hi dad.
Hey guy. Things ok up there? You all right?
I'm fine dad.
Well good. Just confirming. You'll be on the 3:50 Wednesday afternoon.
Well dad, actually I thought I'd take the morning train on Thanksgiving -- got a lot of studying, papers, you know, lab experiments --
Lab experiments? Right smart guy -- Paul, you know your mother's gonna be disappointed not to see more of you -- In fact, let me make this more than a simple request guy, I think you should...

(on TV, from San Clemente press conference)  Well, with regard to the questions as to why Americans feel we were wrong to make the tapes, that is not particularly surprising. I think that most Americans do not like the idea of taping conversations and, frankly, it is not something that particularly appeals to me...
Hold on for a second. (turning) Wendy, you want-to say hi to your brother? She frowns.
Come on! She gets up sullenly and goes to the phone.
Charles.
Charles. Have you been keeping out of my shit? Have you refrained from entering the sacred precincts of my room?
I have not touched your sh-- (looks at father) Stuff. You watching this?
Watching what?
Nixon, doofus! It's incredible. He should be shot.

(overhearing) Hey, that's the president of the goddam United States you're talking about, Wendy! From the kitchen, Elena overhears. She's dressed to go ou but in the process of making a Kraft macaroni and cheese dinner for Wendy.

He's a liar! (still talking more to her father than into the phone) Dean told him on March 21st about Kalmback and Hunt, all about the payoffs to the Watergate burglars, so you tell me where the so-called "Dean Report" is, but you can't because it doesn't exist, because he lied about Haldeman and Erlichman and the April 17 tape, that's why! Liar! Ben retreats, going to the wet bar to pour another drink.
(muttering) OK, OK, the defense rests. (to Elena in the kitchen) Want another?
No thank you. We should be off.
Gotcha. He puts the bottle back down without pouring.

(on the phone) Hey Charles. Charles, calm down -- I wasn't in on it. Elena, putting on her coat, comes into the den and gives Wendy a kiss on the forehead as Wendy mumbles her good-by to Paul on the phone.

Dinner's on the counter. We'll be at the Williams's -- you know the number.  (takes the phone from Wendy) Paul. Hi. Is there anything you'll want, any particular kind of food or snack or anything we can stock up on?... You're all right? ... OK. See you next week. I love you. Back to Nixon on the TV.

We must recognize that one excess begets another, and that the extremes of violence in the 1960s contributed to the extremes of Watergate... On Wendy as she regards the TV, hearing her parents' farewells as they leave through the front door.
A large New England Colonial, with a few modern additions touches. We hear the sound of dinner chatter.

The kitchen door swings open into the dining room, and Mi and Sandy Williams emerge, each holding platters of food. Mikey, 15-and-a-half, lost in space, and Sandy, 14, a sul and barely pubescent boy, each have towels draped over th forearms -- they are the evening's "waiters". They move unsteadily to the table, at which sit their par Janey (38, a hard-edged, sharp-witted beauty) and Jim (43 large and a bit goofy, a genius inventor), together with their guests, Ben and Elena Hood, and neighbors Dorothy a Ted Franklin. We jump cut through the evening's conversations, seen mos from the furtive POV's of the boys.
His brother came back --
From where?
Vietnam.
Oh. Are we going to talk about this, about...?
You should hear. It's very sad, he was --
Janey is whispering something into Mikey's ear, who retur to the kitchen.
It was a benefit for the ACLU or something, and Harry Reems himself was there --
The man with the -- from Deep Throat?
The very one -- something about a first amendment defense fund -- well I believe in it --
Ted took me to see it.
Ted, how romantic.
I have to say, the movie didn't do much for me. But being in that theater, surrounded by all those horny young college boys and perverts, there was something in the air that --
The boys are pouring wine.

-- pulls right up to the pump, jumps out like there's no gas shortage, oblivious, and by this point everybody in line's piling out of their cars ready to kill the guy, when they notice it's that Reverend Edwards --
The Unitarian? The new one?
Yeah -- claims he pulled off Creek Road and didn't notice the line going back Mill Street for half a mile.
He's either got his head in the clouds or up his --
I hear he's slept with half the women in his congregation --
Lucky bastard! As this is said, Mikey accidentally spills some wine on B

Hell! -- I mean, no problemo there Mikey. Here, I -- Janey leans over with her napkin and attempts a cursory w of Ben's pants. Is there a just barely noticeable frisson between Ben and Janey as she removes the napkin? If there Elena doesn't -- or pretends not to -- notice.

The boys, now in pajamas (Sandy's with padded feet, Mikey combination of t-shirt and pj bottoms) are bringing out coffee and dessert. The adults eye Mikey's handling of th coffee pot with some nervousness.
(unconvincing) So fascinating. Do you get free tickets to the movies, that kind of thing?
No, my job is just to analyze the entertainment stocks and advise our institutional investors on where to put their money. It's --
Don't be so modest, Ben. It's a job that requires a certain prescience with regards to entertainment trends. You were the first to predict that Billy Jack would be a hit --
(with a bit too much conviction)  And as usual no one believed me... Silence.
The dinner party has moved to the living room for after dinner drinks. Elena remains behind to help Janey pick up table. She stacks a plate on top of another.
Please don't.
It's not a bother.
I insist. (beat) Don't touch them. Elena realizes that there's an edge to Janey's voice.
Oh.
(realizing she's gone too far) It's really quite all right.
Of course.
The party progresses. Mikey and Sandy are lying on their stomachs at the top of the stairs, out of sight.
And to think -- they met at a key party of all things.
A key party?

You know, it's a California thing. That scuzzy husband of hers dragged her kicking and screaming to one when they were out in L.A. you know, the men put their car keys in a bowl, and then at the end of the evening the women line up and fish them out and go home with whoever's keys they've got. Anyhow that's how she met this Rod person or whatever his name is and he's left his wife and she's packing for California. Irwin is devastated. It's so ironic.
Ironic?
(caught out) Well, um, yes. Ironic. His name is Rod.
The guests are leaving. The men shake hands, the women ki and the men and women awkwardly peck each others' cheeks.
Thank you Janey.
It was lovely!
Hey Jim, next time you've got to fill me in on whatever it is you're up to these days.
Will do.
At the top of the stairs, a rather dejected Sandy and Mik finish spying on the leave-takings below. Mikey nudges Sa and they silently head back the upstairs hall.

They enter Mike's room -- the door has a "nuclear waste  positively no admittance" sign on it. As Mikey reaches his bed, he doubles over, groaning, and starts to make retching noises. He then throws himself on the bed, his head leaning over the far side. Sandy walks over and sees a pile of vomit next to the bed Taken aback for a moment, he then reaches forward and pic it up -- it's fake plastic vomit. He throws it on top of Mike's back, but Mikey doesn't take notice.
Stupid! (pause, looking sullenly at Mike's back) Is Wendy Hood your girlfriend?
(not looking up, but alarmed) Who said so?
No one.

I don't have a girlfriend. Mikey returns to his reading -- a copy of The Sensuous Wo obviously well pawed over. He absentmindedly picks his no As he flips the pages, a beautiful, almost electrical HUM SOUND begins to fill his ears. He frowns and pauses to li to it. Sandy, who has picked up a balsa wood miniature plane, obviously doesn't hear it. Mikey focuses on the plane as Sandy waves it through the Perhaps the hum is the sound of its engines as it soars through the sky...
There is a large poster of a cartoon version of Richard N "Tricky Dick" -- on her wall. Wendy is on the phone to he friend Beth.
-- he knows that when the March 24th tape -- you know with Dean, where Dean tells him that there's a cancer growing on the presidency -- She pauses as Beth asks a question.
Who? No way. He's like a big infected whitehead wearing jeans. I wouldn't -- She hears the downstairs door open.
(whispering) -- shit, it's my parents. She turns her light out.
Ben and Elena walking past Wendy's room to their bedroom.

You'd think she'd learn how to cook a chicken, eh? My drumstick was still frozen when you cut inside there. I'm probably going to get whatever that disease -- and Jim, how that guy ever became a millionaire -- He pauses before a hall table, and, with his eyes, traces telephone cord under Wendy's room.
Hmm. I knew she'd still be up. Watch this -- But Elena simply continues into the master bedroom. He starts to pull gently on the cord. And continues pulli No response for a few seconds. Then:
(yelling behind her door) Dad stop it!
Get to sleep young lady -- and I mean it. Wendy opens the door to her room.
Fascist!
If I were a fascist I would have sent you to one of those Southern military academies a long time ago. Now get to bed. She slams the door. He opens it.
Ben enters the room, angry.
Hey! Wendy jumps into bed and under the covers, pulling them u over her head. He stands over her, looking down at the crumpled pile of sheet and blanket.
(softening) Hey, kiddo. Sleep well, huh. He places his hand where her cheek should be, and caresse the sheet.
(without pulling the sheet down, but nicely) Good-night dad.
Good night kiddo. Ben turns to the door, where he sees a silent Elena stand in her nightgown, a slight smile on her face.
Elena is sitting cross-legged, eyes closed, on her side o the bed. We hear the toilet flush from the master bath, a see Ben emerge in his boxers. He pauses in front of the b looking at Elena.
(without opening her eyes) You're staring at me.
I wasn't star--
I've been thinking, Ben, about Wendy. I was going to ask if she'd come with me sometime to meet Dr. Woolens.
That shrink -- the one you always wanted me to see? I thought you dropped him.
I did, but -- somebody should probably see her, talk to her... You think she's ok?
Why shouldn't she be? Elena just gives him a look, more sad than angry.
(pause) Then again, why should she be? I mean with us, with our...
So maybe you'll come too?
Oh not again Elena! If we've got problems, why can't you just come out and talk about them.
It's you Ben who needs to talk. I've had my say, and I'm waiting to hear back from you.
Yeah but Elena, even you don't believe all that "I'm OK. You're OK" stuff you keep babbling about -- you say so yourself. I've been all ears for about ten years now on his subject, and --
-- And you haven't moved out yet. It's because you're too lazy, Ben. Too scared or lazy to either deal with us or simply make a decision --
Elena. Silence.
(sighing) Sleep in the study? Please. Ben picks up a pillow and walks out, pausing wistfully at door.
Good night.
Good night.
Wendy hears her parents' door close and sees a strip of l illuminate under her door as the hall light goes on, then off.
A nondescript, cleanly "modern" building. Engraved on the doors: "Shackley and Schwimmer, Securities Brokerage - Established 1964"

head_text.subj: INT. SHACKLEY AND SCHWIMMER CONFERENCE ROOM. DAY

text: Ben, seated, is finishing a brief presentation to a small group of men, which includes George Clair, mid-thirties, unctuously handsome.

But what, exactly, is stagflation, this mixture of inflation and stagnation, and how should we in the securities industry understand and accommodate it? Well -- and I hope I'm not out of bounds here - think of the money supply as a large male organ, continuously inflating, and yet, the societal vaginal cavity simply wants more. As the vicious circle of higher returns without real satisfaction continues, the money-organ may seem to be in demand, but in fact even the most inflated capital is unwanted. This is why I suggest that while we engage this mawing abyss for the highest returns, we at the same time fantasize, so to speak, of the safe harbor of capital appreciation. The aging boss nods agreement.
(more or less mumbling) Brilliant, brilliant. George Clair just grins.
Ben is gathering papers, readying to leave. He looks up t see George Clair in his doorway.
Hey there Benjie, you're becoming quite the in-house philosopher. When do you have time to think up all that stuff -- Shackley sure eats it up.

head_text.subj: HALL IN FRONT OF BEN HOOD'S OFFICE

text: As we see that Clair is deftly fondling Hood's attractive secretary as she is seated in the cubicle beside the door his office. She looks up coyly at Clair, hidden for the moment from Ben's view. Ben comes out of his office, pulling his coat on. Clair a the secretary pull back, but it's clear that Ben has some sense of what's transpiring between them.
George, I'm just trying to get a global view of things -- can't just look at the small picture. There's an obvious rivalry between the two of them.
And speaking of which, you have those market share charts Mr. Shackley was asking about?
Gotcha George, not a problem. Tomorrow. Hey, you want to start covering the old filmed entertainment sector yourself?
Ben you know that's your territory  - and I wouldn't dream to trespass  - you're the expert. Hey, how do you think Paramount's gonna do with that Blatty novel, what's it called? The Exorcist?

Overpriced bomb, cost over $6 million -- no stars, and no one's into the horror genre these days anyway. I'm advising the company recommend reducing positions there. It's disaster films that are gonna stay at the top.
Brilliant. Hey, you heading out a little early today?
Got a meeting uptown.
(already moving off) Right o'.
Up the organization! (then, to himself) Bastard. The secretary pretends not to hear.
An august New York institution. To establish.

A stuffy, Ivy League atmosphere. A decades-old tradition serving overcooked American food. Ben is seated across fr his father, Harold Hood, a retired curmudgeon. There is a walker parked by Harold's chair.
(waylaying a passing waiter)  I'd asked for that double martini about three hours ago!
Coming right up, sir.
So asking me out for lunch -- what prompted this exceptional event? -- Of course I'm paying.
We don't have to always go to your club, dad.
And why are you still calling me dad? You're forty years old already, and --
-- Well what am I supposed to call you?
That's besides the point. The martini arrives, along with Ben's beer.
I was actually trying to see about getting a little advice, you know --
Advice? I'm supposed to be getting the stock tips from you, Ben. Unless - have you quit your job? They fired you?
You know, dah-- He looks up and sees his father slurping his martini, not paying attention.
Actually it's not about work, it's advice about --
Oh for crying out loud Ben, you don't mean to tell me that your marriage is going down the drain now --
Well, Elena and I have kind of been talking, not really talking, but --
-- Your mother, God bless her, stood by me for forty-two years -- we never once contemplated divorce  - I assume you're talking here about divorce? The very thought --
But dad, you guys truly hated each other, I mean really hated each --

-- Waiter! Where's my cobb salad?  (back to Ben) You want advice Ben? If your big brother were still alive I'd have him go out into the back yard and beat some sense into your head. Look kid, you married that woman against my advice --
-- What advice? You never --
That's besides the point. The point is if I'd had any sense in me I'd have divorced your mother 40 years ago, and that's the truth, and here it is, 1972 --
-- 73, and divorce is as easy as paying off a traffic ticket, and for crying out loud, Ben, be a man and just get it over with. I would have if I'd had the chance. Ben ponders, as the food arrives.
(weakly) But...
But what?
But I -- well maybe I love her. Elena. His father rolls his eyes and stabs his salad with a fork
Christ Ben! Make up your mind and eat your lunch.

Elena browses the self-help section. A longish-haired, slightly gone-to-seed, but still handsome clergyman pause next to her. He's wearing an ecclesiastical collar and be bottoms. He pulls out a copy of Me, Myself and I, glancing again a Elena.
Elena. Elena Hood, am I right?
Yes.
Reverend Edwards. Philip Edwards. You came by and checked out the congregation a couple of times last year.
Yes, it was -- I ended up --
(smiling) No need to make excuses --

head_text.subj: EXT. NEW CANAAN HIGH SCHOOL FIELD. DAY

text: A cool gray afternoon. A group of boys are playing flag football on the field, while two groups of girls are gath underneath the bleachers at either end, warily smoking c1garettes. Wendy, Beth, and a couple of other girls are gathered in group.
(referring to one of the girls gathered in the other group) She said you licked Dave Brewster's weenie in the third floor bathroom.

She's a liar. I wouldn't touch Dave Brewster's dick if you paid me. It's probably crawling with v.d. after he put it in her, which he did. The conversation peters out at this point, as the two gro of girls give each other the hairy eyeball from afar. Wendy looks through from beneath the bleacher seats onto field where the boys are playing. A group of boys break from a huddle, Mikey among them. The quarterback takes the hike and Mikey runs out for a p As he runs, his breathing increases in volume, filling hi ears, and transforming into the humming sound he'd heard before. The quarterback spots him and throws a long one. He runs in an oblivion of beautiful white sound. The ball drops next to him as he continues, in a world of own, to run. Suddenly, the humming ends and he stops and turns around, see all the other kids just standing there looking at him One of them makes a pot-smoking gesture, as if that's the explanation.
(as he returns to the group, ball in hand) Did anybody hear that? The other kids snicker. Wendy looks on, and catches Mikey eye for a fleeting moment.
I gotta go. She takes hold of her bicycle and pushes off.
Elena and Philip are seated at a booth.
It's been a tremendously transformative year -- maybe a little controversial of course, but we're breaking down the old Unitarian barriers --
I suppose my reluctance was the group aspect of it -- I've never been much of a joiner, although I still consider myself a somewhat religious person --

Well I of course flatter myself that our church is not exactly what most people would call organized religion -- at times it's the disorganization that's liberating -- and of course I've begun to minister much more in what one might call therapeutic environments, in small groups, and one on one, couples -- Elena looks outside the window, and sees Wendy speed past her bicycle.
(cutting him off) My daughter. I haven't been on a bike for years. (still not really looking at him) When was the last time you rode a bike?
(a bit taken aback by the abrupt topic change) They say you never forget.
(jarred back to his presence)  Forget what?
Forget how to ride a bike. Silence.
No, of course you don't, you're right.

head_text.subj: EXT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY

text: Wendy pulls her bike up to the back, locks it, and walks

head_text.subj: INT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY

text: Wendy moves with a certain amount of stealth through the aisles, arriving at the candy selection. She looks around. She takes a package of twinkies and slips them into the oversized pockets of her painter's pants. She turns around, and her breath goes out of her -- an OL WOMAN has been watching her shoplift. The woman looks sad at her, but says nothing. Wendy slowly walks past her and the back door of the store. The woman looks on.

head_text.subj: EXT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY

text: As she walks her bike onto the sidewalk, Wendy comes acro Sandy.
Hey Wendy.
Hey Sandy.
Mikey was looking for you.
Yeah? See ya. She pushes off on her bike. Sandy gazes after her. He takes his G.I. Joe out of his c pocket, and points it at her.
Bam.
Wendy flies along on her bike. It's a desolately beautifu fall day.

head_text.subj: EXT. SILVER MEADOWS PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE. DAY

text: Wendy rides by the front gates of the posh grounds of the private psychiatric clinic. A security guard leans agains booth. Once a bit past the gate, she gets off her bike and walks into a grove of trees near the front drive.
Mikey is waiting amid the trees next to his bike as Wendy arrives.
Want some gum?
Sure. (pulling them out of her pocket) Twinkie?
(opens his mouth, displaying the gum on his tongue) I'm chewing. She puts the Twinkies back, and pops the gum in her mouth They stand together chewing.
(after a pause) Did you tell Sandy?
Tell Sandy? What? Wendy doesn't say anything.
You didn't tell him either, did you?

head_text.subj: EXT. SILVER MEADOWS SWIMMING POOL. DAY

text: The wind is picking up and the light is fading. Mikey and Wendy climb the fence around the pool, which is empty and half-covered in dead leaves and twigs. They climb down into the concrete recess and walk into th deep end, leaning against the far wall of the pool. They each matter-of-factly take their gum out and put it behind their ears. They begin not so much to kiss as to place their tongues each others' mouths. We see them from high above the pool, as the dead leaves swirl lightly around them, Mikey groping under Wendy's poncho.
To establish.

A couple are in the final throes of lovemaking. We see Ja Williams's face, more or less enjoying the proceedings. T man gives a final heave and groan, and rolls off to revea himself to be -- Ben Hood.
Janey smokes a cigarette. Ben is babbling.

We were golfing, and you know, golfing to me is something I'm supposed to enjoy, and I was on the goddam golf team in college, so it's something one would assume I do well -- I used to do well -- but basically these days golfing for me is like hoeing, or plowing. Janey smiles briefly at this.

It's like farming. I am basically chewing up large tracts of expensively landscaped scenery with overpriced sticks, and George Clair has obviously, in the mere two years since he joined the firm, he has obviously been taking secret lessons with a golf pro, and I assume the entirety of his disposable income has been devoted to humiliating me on the golf course. And the guy talks - incessantly -- throughout the entirety of the miserable 18 holes  - on topics that are the supposed domain of my department --
Ben--
Yeah?
(gently) You're boring me. I have a husband. I don't particularly feel the need for another.
You have a point there. That's a very good point. We're having an affair. Right. An explicitly sexual relationship. Your needs. My needs. You're absolutely right.
You should probably get dressed. The boys will be home soon.
Gotcha. She wraps a blanket around herself and gets up.

head_text.subj: EXT. BACK OF WILLIAMS HOUSE. EVENING

text: Ben cautiously walks out he back door and heads for the s gate.
Wendy enters the house as Elena is finishing supper preparations.
Hi mom.
Hi Wendy. Without waiting for instructions, Wendy starts pulling ou plates and silverware and setting the table.
I saw you on your bike today.
With Mikey?
Who?
Nobody.
Mikey Williams?
We were just riding around. Elena takes this in.
Well, you looked very -- free -- when I saw you. Wendy continues setting the table.
Weightless almost -- as if I were seeing my own memories of being a girl. There was something internal about it.
Mom. Are you ok?
Wendy, of course. I'm sorry. You must think I'm ripe to be checked into Silver Meadows.
You're not a psycho!
The people at Silver Meadows aren't psychos.
I know. They're rich drug addicts and celebrities. When I saw James Taylor there, and --
We've been through this Wendy  James Taylor was actually at that clinic up near Boston.
Well, I saw what I saw, and if you don't want to believe me --
Oh Wendy. Wendy frowns.
They need the money for my band uniform at school.
I thought you quit the band - I never hear you practice anymore.
I don't really need to practice. I just play a few notes, you know, so I thought maybe I'd stay in.
Well, I'm sure your father and I would love to hear what you're playing these days. Maybe after dinner.

Ben and Elena take their seats on the sofa. Wendy stands before them holding an enormous trombone, with a music st and sheet music in front of her. She puffs a series of seemingly disconnected notes in wal time. When she's done, she looks up from the sheet music to her parents. They applaud.
Can't wait to see how it fits in with all the other instruments. Elena gives him a look.
Elena is sorting through bills and writing checks at the kitchen table. Ben comes in and fills a glass with ice.
The Halfords have invited us again this year.
You want to go?
What do you think?
Well, it is a neighborhood tradition. He comes up behind her, looks down at the checkbook.
I'm, uh, going to bed.
So early?
Rough day. Good night. He leans over and kisses her on the cheek. She sniffs.
Is that a new aftershave? He recoils a bit.
Oh yeah. Musk, or something. You like it?
Hmm. Good night. He walks uncertainly from the room. Does she suspect?
Mikey is painfully at work writing an English essay. Sand comes to the door with a geometry textbook.
Mikey?
Yeah?
Geometry?
Sure, anything but this English. Sandy puts the open textbook in front of him.
Why are you so good at math but not in English?
I'm not good at math. Just geometry. He looks at the book.

(drawing out his examples on a piece of paper)  It's like, you know when they say "two squared"? And you think it means 2 times 2, equals 4? But really they really mean a square. A square with a side of two. And the area of the square is four. Like every time you use the word, like squared, or cubed, it's really space, it's not numbers, it's space. And it's perfect space, but only in your head, because you can't draw a perfect square, like in the material world, but in your mind, you can have perfect space. (pause) You know? As Mikey goes on, we see his geometric doodles, and hear faintly the HUMMING SOUND under his voice.
Yeah. But I just need some help with my homework. A knock at the door. Jim stands in the doorway with a suitcase in his hand.
Hey guys, I'm back.
(honestly confused) You were gone? Sandy looks at Mikey as if pondering a lost cause.

(a look of disappointment)  Yeah Mikey. Yep, I was in Houston, working on some great new ideas about silicon, which comes from sand, very conductive. How you guys doing? How's school? Mikey's still flustered.
Uh, I dunno. OK I guess.
Hmm. Alright! He walks off.
You really didn't notice? Man, he's been gone for three days.
Janey is reading, still dressed, on the bed. She nods to as he enters with his suitcase.
Good trip? He nods and puts his suitcase down, then sits heavily on side of the bed.
(as he sits) You bet. It turns out it's a water bed, and his weight creates a w that nearly pushes Janey off her edge of the bed.
Jesus, Jim!
(jumping up, which only creates another wave) Sorry honey. Hell, we've got to trade this thing in for a normal bed.
Just be careful.
(as he begins to unpack) You notice anything with Mikey lately? The kid seemed a little out of it tonight, eh?
Tonight? Jim, he's been out of it since he was born.
Hell, I guess he takes after me, huh? He laughs to himself. She gives him a look.
Elena and Philip Edwards are having coffee again.

In many ways, the church-bound tradition of the father, son, and holy ghost is simply a version of the parent-child-adult triad within us all. It's a primitive set of symbols for our inner psychology.
You're saying that Christ is the child, and --
-- And God the angry parent, and the Spirit the hope of an integrated adult self.
All well and good -- But tell me again what is it exactly that you believe in?
You ask what the point is?
That's right.
Self-realization. Ministering to help people reach their fullest potential. Would you believe me if I told you I want you to see yourself reach your fullest potential and self-realization?
I would say it sounds like you're trying to get me into bed.
If that's a potential you see yourself fulfilling... I mean...  (flustered) My, I sound a bit --
I'm sorry. That was stupid of me. I didn't mean to be so rude.
You weren't. You actually, for some reason, you have the effect on me of making me feel just a tiny bit ashamed of myself.
But not too ashamed.
(smiling) Now you are being rude.
And you're still trying to get me into bed.
Ouch. Just then, Dorothy Franklin passes by their table, a smir firmly implanted on her face.
Hello you two. Am I barging in on some kind of religious study group? Elena, you look marvelous. Will I see you and Ben at the Halford's?
I suppose we'll make an appearance.
And Reverend Edwards? Did you make the list?
(laughing) I believe so Mrs. Franklin.
With the two of you there it will be positively a revival! I'm off! She scurries out of the coffee shop.
I'm afraid she's something of a gossip, isn't she?
(gathering her things to go) I'm afraid people around here provide her with quite a bit to gossip about.  (getting up) Take care.
That I will indeed.
Mikey is reading his English paper before the class.

Because of molecules we are connected to the outside world from our bodies. Like when you smell things, because when you smell a smell it's not really a smell, it's a part of the object that has come off of it -- molecules. So when you smell something bad, it's like in a way you're eating it. This is why you should not really smell things, in the same way that you don't eat everything in the world around you  - because as a smell, it gets inside of you. So the next time you go into the bathroom after someone else has been there, remember what kinds of molecules you are in fact eating. An embarrassed silence.

Band practice. The New Canaan High School band is doing a wind version of a popular rock tune. In front, there's Wendy, in halter top and hip-hugging be bottoms, incongruously blowing away on her trombone -- th being her one stab at extracurricular activities. In the flute section directly behind her is Sandy, piping away on a tiny piccolo. He sits on a riser slightly eleva above her. He directs downward at Wendy a protracted regard, a look intense concentration on his face.

Wendy's backside, her pants pushed outward in the back, affording Sandy a libido-charged view of the top of her b crack. Push in on a close-up of this cherished abstract landscap then back to Sandy's furrowed face.
Ben and Harold are at their table again. Lunch is being cleared.
It's not the taxes I object to. It's all the fines and penalties.
Alright dad. But you sold the house, you didn't tell anyone, including the IRS, and I'd of certainly liked to have seen if there was any old stuff --
It was all junk! Another pause. Ben decides not to pursue an overworked to
Oh. Elena wanted to know when we could expect you on Thanksgiving. It's just going to be you this year.

Ben, I'm going to Florida. I hate Thanksgiving and I hate the cold. I have a new nurse. She's a negro, she weighs three hundred pounds, and I've decided to leave my entire estate to her. Ben spits his drink out.
What?
Jesus, Benjamin, you're still as gullible as ever.
That was a joke? You don't tell jokes.
I thought I'd start trying. If you don't mind. But I am going to Florida and I do have a new nurse.
Ben sits in the moving train, commuting home. He puts dow his paper to look at this fellow passengers. [NOTE: He is the same seat as was Paul at the beginning of the film.]
Elena sits in a yoga pose.
Elena enters the garage from the kitchen and turns the li on. She finds an old bicycle and pulls it out.

Elena rides her bike into town, infused with the girlish sense of freedom she imagined for her daughter. Suddenly, there's a pop -- a tire is blown out. She slows down and gets off the bike. As she bends to look at the wheel, a station wagon slows near her. The driver's side window rolls open. It's Janey Williams.
Need a lift?
Elena sits in the passenger seat. The two women are obvio uncomfortable with each other. Silence.
Thanks again. For the dinner.
Thanks for eating it. I don't know why I even pretend I can cook.
I used to know how to cook.
It's not like we're too busy. They smile, barely.
I'm thinking of going back to school.
Social work?
How'd you know?
Educated guess.
I'm that predictable? No, you don't have to answer that. It's just that with the kids almost grown --
You don't have to apologize. I'm too much of a cynic. You actually seem to be trying to figure things out -- don't mind me. She pulls the car over.

head_text.subj: EXT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY

text: Janey's car pulls to the curb.
Here you are.
(opening her door) Thanks for the lift. If the bike's any bother--
None at all. I'll leave it in front of your garage. Happy Thanksgiving.
Elena watches the car pull away. She turns and walks into store.

Elena moves through the aisles, putting various sundries a basket. She pauses in front of the lipsticks. She picks up a lipstick, looks at it, then quietly places in her pocket. We see her reflection in the security mirror above the ai as she quickly exits the store. The middle-aged lady behind the counter watches her leave

In a wide shot, from across the street, we see Elena leav the store, followed by the shopkeeper who runs behind her taps her on the shoulder. They converse for a minute, and Elena is accompanied back into the store. Through the store windows we see her take the lipstick ou her purse. She's obviously distraught -- offering to pay, talking quickly, etc. The shopkeeper is holding a telepho not yet decided on whether to call her in.

To find yourself in the Negative Zone, as the Fantastic Four often do, means that all everyday assumptions are inverted -- even the invisible girl herself becomes visible, and so she loses the last semblance of her power.
Close on images from The Fantastic Four.

head_text.subj: POWERS ARE HALVED. WE CAN DO

text: Paul sits reading on his way home.
Janey pulls up in the driveway. As she gets out of the ca she hears a small explosion from the back of the house.

Janey comes around the back to discover Sandy stuffing a model airplane with m-80 firecrackers. He lights them and runs back a safe distance. The plane explodes, its wrecka joining the debris from a few other dolls, models, and to
Sandy! Sandy looks up -- busted. Janey marches over to him.
You little idiotic prick, you could blow yourself fucking sky high with all this demented crap. Sandy looks on the verge of tears. She softens and bends to him.
(sighing) Hey. (picking up the firecrackers) I'll take this stuff.
You going to tell dad?
Would it matter? (sees something else lying on the ground) And what's that?
(sniffling) You know, it's the whip -- the one uncle Frank got me from Mexico.
It's not packed with explosives, is it?
No!
(going into the house) Play with the whip.
Mikey and Wendy are in front of the TV, watching a rerun Divorce Court.
Oh. Hi Wendy.
Hi Mrs. Williams.
Mikey, have you heard the explosions coming from the backyard? (he stares blankly at her) Do you know what Sandy's been up to?
(honestly oblivious, as usual) I dunno. She pauses, then walks into the kitchen.
Sandy flicks his enormous whip in the direction of a smal bush. One by one, he snaps off its leaves.
Janey hauls a turkey out of a bag and into the fridge.
Mikey and Wendy are still in front of the TV. Janey comes in again and looks at them.
Don't you kids have homework?

(without looking up, in unison) Thanksgiving break. She walks out of the room again. Sandy comes in, whip in hand, looks over at Mikey and Wen then walks over to them, and, without a word, slumps down beside them and watches the TV.
Elena walks unsteadily, pausing to rest against a brick w She takes a deep breath, then walks to a corner where a l taxi station wagon sits idling. She gestures to the drive who beckons her in.
Later, still mentally devolving in front of the TV, but w various junk food detritus surrounding them and a differe show, a rerun of the original Highway Patrol. Sandy wanders off.
Later. Wendy gets up, goes upstairs, and wanders down the hall t the bathroom. She gets to the door just as Sandy gets there from the opposite direction.
After you. Sandy hesitantly opens the door, as Wendy still hovers by
Well, you can...
Hey Sandy, what were you blowing up out there? Your mom was pretty p.o.'d.
All my model planes.
The ones you built?

They were old. And they couldn't fly anyhow. I'm going to get a radio-controlled airplane at Christmas, and then I'll stuff it full of m-80s and then fly it into Mrs. Burgess's English class and blow it up.
I have to go to the bathroom.
Yeah. But he stays put, unaware it seems that he's blocking the doorway. Wendy looks around -- no one in sight.
I'll show you mine if you show me yours. Sandy goes wide eyed, and almost against his will backs i the bathroom like a feather.
Mikey looks up from the TV, wondering where Wendy is. He another Pringle.

Wendy flips up her dress for Sandy. He slowly unzips, his hand unsteady. We can tell from the look on Wendy's face that she's feeling a bit sorry for t little guy. Suddenly Sandy turns beet red, and bursts into tears.
What do you want?! What do you want? Get out! Get out of here! The door flips open -- and Janey Williams appears.
(sizing up the situation)  Shit.
Janey is giving Wendy a lecture

A person's body is his temple, Wendy. This body is your first and last possession. Now as your own parents have probably told you, in adolescence our bodies tend to betray us. That's why, in Samoa and in other developing nations, adolescents are sent out into the woods, unarmed, and they don't come back until they've learned a thing or two.
Wendy is led to the door by Mrs. Williams. Wendy trades a glance with a sullen Mikey, who sits in th living room pretending to ignore her.

Wendy walks her bike with the wind in her face. From behind her, Mikey rides up on his bike and rides alongside her. She doesn't look at him. Trying to stay on his bike, but moving slowly, he wobbles nearly falling off.
I don't ever want to see you.
Then why'd you come after me?
The taxi pulls up. Elena gets out and pays the driver.
Ben is in front of the open freezer, trying to get someth out. He hears Elena come in the front door.

Elena. I need some help here if this thing's gonna defrost by tomorrow. She comes up and together they tug and pull until they succeced in extracting a large, frozen turkey. As they pu it out, it slips from their hands and, after a dull thump slides along the floor. They smile. Elena bends over to pick it up. Ben observes her. She not his look.
Here. He goes over and picks up the turkey, placing it in the s He looks back at her and notices her vaguely distraught l
You all right there?
Oh. Sure, I -- Did you remember to pick up the cranberry sauce?
Um, yes. They stand together, his concern and her vulnerability forming an awkward attraction between them.
Because you like it on your turkey sandwiches.
I do. I'm -- are you...?
I... I think I am...
(pause) You know Elena, I've been thinking--
Ben, maybe no talking right now? If you start talking, you're going to-- She kisses him as if she needed him.
Ben and Elena enter their bedroom. Elena closes the door quietly behind her.
Ben and Elena undress shyly. They make love. Elena's face is almost fearful.
Elena and Ben lie in bed side by side in the pale afterno light. Neither speaks. Ben turns on his side, and notices small tear forming in Elena's eyes.
You crying?
I'm just sad Ben -- I mean it was... you were, but, you know. I just don't know...
(gently making light) Whatever that means Elena -- And you complain about me not communicating... I thought it was --
No, I didn't mean to sound negative. It was -- But Ben.  (beat) What is going to happen with us? Have you --
You have to bring this up now? What? Did I do something here? Is that it? Is it something I did?
I wasn't accusing you, Ben. It's just that we've got to be honest. Not just with ourselves, but with the children.
(pause, sitting up) Hell, I know. I -- I guess if you want to accuse me, you've got -- (looks at watch) Oh hell! I've got to pick up Paul. I almost forgot. He gets up and starts to get dressed.
You were saying? He smells the armpits of the shirt he's putting on.
Yikes -- I was hoping to wear this thing to the Halford's Friday.
That shirt?
What?
Leave it -- I'll wash it for you. He looks at her ruefully.
Wendy walks and Mikey rides along.
You have to follow me?
I dunno. I -- They're now in front of the Hood's house.
Ben exits the house in a rush, and sees Wendy and Mikey o the street in front.
Hey there Mikey, how's business?
(tripping off of his bike) Business? Uh, I dunno. Ben grimaces, fiddles for his car keys. As Mikey remounts and rides off, Wendy passes her father the driveway.
I'm picking up Paul at the station  - want to come?
Nah.
What you been up to?
Nothing.
Wendy enters the house and climbs the stairs. She sees the crumpled bed sheets in her parents' room and hears Elena in the shower.
Paul walks to the parking lot with his father, who carrie his duffel bag.
Ben's car heading back to the house with Paul.
So how's school treating you?
All right.
Classes?
Good.
Grades?
Fine.
Anyone special? You know...
Hnnn.
Well it's good to see you -- we miss you around the house and all, but this St. Peter's, it's top of the line, eh?
Yeah.
You know Paul, I've been thinking, maybe this is as good a time as any to have a little talk, you know, about -- well -- He makes a sharp turn. Paul puts his arms up on the dashb to steady himself.
(nervous) About?

Well, the whole gamut. Facts of life and all. Some fatherly advice, because, I tell you, there's things happening that you're probably old enough... well... (pause) For example, on the self-abuse front -- now this is important - it's not advisable to do it in the shower -- it wastes water and electricity and because we all expect you to be doing it there in any case -- and, um, not onto the linen, and not on your sister's underwear or any clothing belonging to your mother -- He pauses to gauge the effect of his monologue on his son then continues.
Uh, Dad -- Just then Ben runs a stop sign and almost slams into anot car.
Holy! Well. If you're worried about anything, just feel free to ask, and, uh, we can look it up.
Uh, dad, you know I'm 16.
All the more reason for this little heart to heart... great.
The car pulls up. Paul gets out, looking shell-shocked. H sees Wendy waving to him from a second floor window. He n back.
Um, Paul. On second thought, can you do me a favor and pretend I never said any of that.
Sure dad.
Thanks. In the doorway, Elena waits.
Paul knocks on Wendy's bedroom door. She opens it.
Hello, Charles.
Greetings, Charles.
Paul and Wendy sit on the floor.
How are the parental units functioning these days?
Dad's like doing his Up With People routine, mom hasn't been saying much.
I don't know. Dad seems a little weird.
Yeah well wait till mom opens her mouth. They both ponder silently. Then:
May I operate your telephonic apparatus?
Why don't you use the phone downstairs?
Calling an individual, Charles, in New York. Confirming a social outing for Friday night.
Can I come?
It's a one-on-one kind of date thing.
With who?
Her name's Libbets.
Libbets? What kind of a name is Libbets?
Morning. To establish.
Elena is coming out of the master bathroom in a robe, a t wrapped around her head.
The turkey in?
Stuffed and baking.
Ben Hood pads down the hall in his bathrobe, tries the bathroom door. It's locked.
Anyone home?
The shower is running, but Paul is standing by the open window, puffing on a joint and trying to blow the smoke outside.
I'll be out in a second. Ben walks back to the bedroom, smirking.
Sure you will.
One by one, each member of the Hood carried in a final it to place on the overstuffed Thanksgiving table. Then, one one, they each silently take their seats. They look over the table. No one moves.

Well, it's great we can all be together. And this Thanksgiving, no hysteria, no yelling, especially with grandpa not here, although we miss him. So let's do it right and actually, Wendy, why don't you say grace. You used to love to say grace, remember. Wendy grimaces, as they all bow their heads slightly.
Dear Lord, thank you for Thanksgiving, and for letting us white people kill all the Indians... Everyone looks up.
... and steal their tribal lands and stuff ourselves like pigs Mutterings and groans: "Wendy!" "For Christ's sake" etc.
... while children in Africa and Asia are napalmed and --
Jesus all right enough! They all unceremoniously start to dig in.
Janey Williams is pouring Benjamin Hood a drink from a bo of vodka. Benjamin is already unbuttoned and shoeless; Ja still fully dressed.
Here.
After the Thanksgiving I had, I need it. You having one?
In a bit. She sits next to him, he kisses the back of her neck.
You know, I think Elena might suspect something. Janey gives him a rather contemptuous look.
(thinking aloud) Maybe it's all for the better, you know? Yesterday, at dinner, well, she hasn't said anything... has she acted funny to you, I mean, have you noticed anything?
(almost ironic) Have I noticed anything? I'm not married to her Benjamin, you are. I think you've probably a better vantage point from which to observe her.

Yeah, but, I -- I've been working a lot lately, and -- No, that's not it. I guess we've just been on the verge of saying something, whatever it is, just saying something to each other. On the verge. Janey gets up.
I'll be back. Benjamin looks at her quizzically.
Huh?
Birth control.

Right. Gotcha. She leaves the room. He leans back onto the bed. Sits back up. Takes a sip of vodka. Puts the glass down. Takes his socks off. He's now just his jockey shorts and shirt. Faintly, he hears a door close. The front door? He takes another sip. He hears another sound.
Janey? Nothing. He goes to the door and carefully opens it.
(quietly) Janey? He hears, quite audibly, a car door open, close, Janey's start and pull out. He runs to a front window just in time to catch a glimpse her driving off.
Shit.
Benjamin sits on the guest bed, still in his underwear, drinking from the bottle. He gets up and starts to wander around the house, still holding the bottle.
Benjamin saunters through. He presses on the king-sized b it undulates.
Water bed! Dig it! He wiggles comically, making more waves.
Ben idly goes through Janey's drawers.
He rifles through the bathroom cabinet, checking out the medicines.
He notices a garter belt hanging from the walk-in closet door. He picks it up and twirls it.

Benjamin walks in, an obvious look of distaste. He sorts through a few of Mike's things -- monster eyes t glow in the dark, The Sensuous Woman, etc. He twirls the garter belt absentmindedly, then tosses it the back of Mike's closet.
He finishes putting his clothes back on. As he reaches fo the door, he hears voices and quickly steps back in again Teenage voices. Mikey and Wendy.
See, no one's here. Maybe you want to go to the basement?
Maybe we can just watch some TV.
There's a TV in the basement. Hood hears their steps down into the basement.
Wendy and Mikey stand in the middle of the semi-lit basem
Maybe we can mess around. You know, only if you want to...
I don't know.
Why did you -- with Sandy?
I don't know.
You like him? He worships you. But Wendy doesn't seem to hear -- she's drawn to an objec lying next to a bean bag chair off to one side.
Hey, what's this? With a look of utter fascination, she picks up a Nixon ma looking at it as though it were an archeological find.
Wow!
Wendy! She puts the mask on.

(from behind the mask) I won't take my pants off. But I'll touch it. That's as far as it goes. Mikey looks totally confused. Remaining fully clothed, Wendy loosens Mike's belt, showi no excitement from behind her mask, and lets him climb on of her for a dry hump. Just then, a shaft of light hits them from the top of the stairs -- Ben towers above them, looking down. Mikey flips over immediately and pulls his clothes togeth grabbing a TV Guide as Wendy stands up, the mask still on As Ben descends Mikey, still stuffing his shirt-tail into pants, pretends to flip through the TV Guide.
(muttering) When worlds collide.
Huh?
4:30 movie. When Worlds Collide. Ben arrives, folds his arms.
What the hell are you kids doing down here?
What do you think we're doing, dad?

What do I think? I think you're probably touching each other. I think you're touching that reckless jerk-off, for god's sake, and I think he's trying to get into your slacks. I think, at fourteen years of age, that you're getting ready to give up your girlhood --
Hey, hang on there, Mr. Hood --
Don't you direct a single word at me, Mikey. I don't want to hear it. I'll be speaking with your parents about this situation very soon. Bet your ass on that, son. Young lady?
Talking to me, dad?
Who else would I be talking to? And take that thing off!
(pulling off the mask) Well, then forget all this stern dad stuff.
I'm not interested in your smart ass remarks now, lady. Let's go. Right now. You and I can discuss it on the walk home. She stands next to Mikey for a moment, both on the verge tears.
Hood and Wendy walk through a cold drizzling rain. He looks at her from time to time, then takes her arm.
Look, kiddo, don't worry about it. I really don't care that much. I'm just not sure he's good enough, that's all.
Huh?

I mean, he's not serious, he'll end up living off Janey and Jim, you watch. It's just that you develop a sense when you get older, if things are going to work out or if they won't, and sometimes it's not worth the mess... She looks at him. They keep walking. She walks through a puddle.
Your toes cold?
Yeah. He stops and lifts her in his arms.
I'll carry you up the drive. She puts her arms around his neck and he lifts her up. On her face, as he carries her -- a look of blank but rea intimacy.
Hood and Wendy enter, wet and cold, muttering hellos.
(from the kitchen) Dinner in ten minutes.
You go dry off now. Wendy heads for the stairs, Hood following.
Hood finishes taking off his wet clothes as Elena enters turns on a light. She stands watching him.
Never guess where I found her. Not much response From Elena.

In the basement over at Janey and Jim's. With that weirdo Mikey. Not even a TV on. And they're on the floor and he's got his trousers down though thank goodness she's still dressed. Well, I really let him have it!  (a nervous laugh) ... and Wendy came home peacefully... Hey, should I dress for the Halford's now, or - give me your -
Up to you. I'd like to go early and leave pretty soon after that.
I get you loud and clear... hey, you look nice.
So what were you doing in the Williams' basement anyway?
Oh, just dropping off a coffee cup. Jim left it, last time he was over. It was on the dash of the car. You were, you know, reading, thought I'd just catch some air. Let's eat.
Oh right. The mustache coffee cup. The one that was sitting on the dash.
Yeah, that one.
That one. She walks down to the kitchen, Benjamin following her.
Wendy is already in the kitchen, fishing through the draw for silverware and napkins. Paul enters.
See you.
Stay out of trouble.
You'll be on the 10:30 train?
Paul --
Ah let the guy have his fun. What's the name of this girl with the Park Avenue address?
Libbets. Libbets Casey.
Libbets? What kind of name is Libbets?

A silent dinner of turkey sandwiches with Elena, Benjamin and Wendy. The turkey carcass sits, embarrassed, in the middle of the table. Wendy, finished, gets up from the table. Opens the fridge but finds nothing. Then goes to the candy shelf and grabs some Hot Tamales, leaving the room without a word and goi into the den.
Wendy turns the TV on.
... and that ends today's highlight coverage of the Watergate affair.
Shoot.
Hood and Elena rise from the table with their dishes.
What's for dessert?
See for yourself.
No advice from the experts, huh? His plate slips out of his hands into the trash. He fishe out and sets it on the counter.
Don't start.
You think I --
I have no idea.
What's on your mind? Don't --
It wouldn't make a pleasant evening, if that's what you're after. I don't want to talk about it. Stupid mustache cup.
What do you mean?
Don't be dim.
Elena, what are you're talking about?
I'm not surprised.
Listen, Elena, if you're gonna pull that passive aggressive stuff on me again --
Your unfaithfulness -- that's what I'm trying to talk about. Your unfaithfulness. Your betrayal. Your dalliance. And you won't do me the dignity of being up front about it.
(quieter) Am I unfaithful? Is that what you're trying to say?
It's a starting place.
Well, what kind of faithfulness are you after?
If you're going to insult me --

What else could I be? What else could I be? We're not living in the real world here. You're living out some fantasy land from the past, or some advice or something from those psychoanalysts... there are some hard facts here. Silence.
It's the law of the land... the government, the world, those two guys on the Yankees... And I'm not having any fun at it, I can tell you that. I'm not...
Wendy puts the volume of the TV up, to drown out a conversation she can almost overhear but doesn't want to.

Oh lord. You think I'm so dense. And now you want to be seen with your dense wife at the cocktail party. You want to wear that ridiculous shirt which doesn't go with those pants at all. You want to wear that, and you want me to shake hands with your friends and make conversation and dress up in an outfit that shows a lot of cleavage and you're not going to accord me the respect of talking honestly about this... You don't really know what this feels like.
(whispering) Sure I do. Do I know what loneliness feels like? Sure I do. I know a lot about it, if that's what you mean.
Benjamin. That's supposed to explain it? Seemingly tired, he stands before her. Silence. Elena sig then walks into the den.
We're going to the Halford's. The number's on the calendar in the kitchen. We should be home around 11.
(eyes still glued to the
Is it a big party? A big neighborhood party?
I suppose. Why?
Just curious. If there's a problem, I guess I'll just call you there to interrupt.
What sort of problems are you planning exactly? Elena kisses the top of her head.
(still watching the TV) Oh I thought I'd steal the station wagon, drive up to a commune. Or set the house on fire. You know.
Just bundle up. It's supposed to freeze tonight. We'll see you in the morning.
Elena and Ben emerge from the house, and look up at a darkening, foreboding sky. A light rain falls. They jog toward their car.
The car moves slowly through the rainy suburban streets. Inside, Elena and Ben don't speak.
Their Firebird pulls up. There are already many other car parked on the lawn and driveway.
Hood and Elena enter. Dot Halford accosts them.

Ben, Elena. Wonderful! Wonderful! So wonderful to see you. Finishing the last of a celery canoe, she kisses the air to Ben's ear and gives Elena a manic hug. Then, picking up a white salad bowl from the hall table:
Would you care to play? New this year. Close on: the bowl full of keys.
Strictly volunteer, of course. You can put your coats in the library if you like.
Oh, damn. Uh, I've left the --
You've...
In the car.
Oh, yeah. Yeah, we'll be right back, Dot.
Ben and Elena climb back in the car and close the doors, shivering.
This just isn't the best moment for this.
I know, I know. I had no idea --
That this was going to be a key party?
Yeah, well, if we'd understood we could have invented some kind of excuse. A key party -- did you see how stuffed that bowl was already?
Well?
I think we're here and we don't have to stay -- we ought simply to put in an appearance and then we can head home.
Damn it, Ben --
I'm not staying at this party so we can go home with someone else's wife. That's not why we're here, right? We're simply being neighbors here, and I think we should do just that --
You're not going to --
I'm not.

You have some marker, that's what I think, if you want to know the truth. You have some marker and you're going to put it on the house keys so that Janey can find them and then when I get back to the house I'll find the two of you in there and Wendy'll be able to hear you and Paul will be back and he'll hear you and I'll catch you, that's what I think. She'll be swearing and banging against the wall and I'll catch --
Elena. She rubs her eyes.

Elena, it's not what you think. It's not a big plot. Honestly. Honestly. I don't know if you want to go over this now, but it's just something that comes over me. I don't feel good about it. I know I've done what I didn't want to do. I don't know --
Well, I'm really pleased to hear a confession.
Elena, you're just getting wound up to get wound up.

Thanks for the diagnosis, Ben. Thank you. So let's just go to this fiasco if that's what you want to do. Let's just go on in. I'd rather talk to anyone else but you. She pulls the keys out of the ignition, gets out of the c and slams the door. He follows her.

Oh, Dot! Elena, entering the house again, tosses the keys at Dot Halford, who looks surprised. Hood slides in behind his wife. Dot drops the keys into the bowl. Slow-motion, close up: the keys, on their equine chain, f in with a THUNDEROUS CRASH.

The room is crowded with nervous, expectant couples and various groupings. Elena slips into a side room. Benjamin heads over immediately to the drink table and po a stiff one, turning around to find at his elbow none oth than George Clair.
Benjie!
Clair, George Clair! What the hell brings you to New Canaan?

Well, it's the funniest thing. I've been talking to some investors -- a little outside venture, you understand, between you and me -- about a scheme to manufacture a new Styrofoam packaging. Little peanut like pieces that can really keep an item free from trauma during shipping. Miraculous. Anyway, it turns out the genius behind the whole project is your neighbor, Jim Williams. How about that!
Well, hey, isn't that a one-in-a million coincidence. A real dreamer, Jim Williams, eh?
Darned right. Look here, Benj, whaddya make of this sequel to The Godfather? You think it's gonna work?
Don't see how. I think the public's had its fill of this gangster stuff. No, trust me -- disaster pics. And air hockey.
Yeah, good. Benjamin catches a glimpse of Janey, voluptuously attired across the room.
Well, gonna make a break for the hors d'oeuvres guy.
Yeah, see you bright and early Monday am. (beat) Say, where's the wife?

(winking as he goes) In Rhode Island with the folks. I'm a free agent tonight. At this, they both notice Elena slowly gliding across the other side of the room. Clair gives Ben a sideways glance then moves on. Ben makes straight for Janey, who pretends to be preoccup with a plant.
Oh jeez, Benjie. Well, here you are.
Damn right, but where the hell were you?
(looking around) What are you talking about?

(whispering, but too loudly) Don't bullshit me around, Janey. Jesus Christ, I waited around for more than half an hour, in nothing but my boxer shorts, and -- and what's all that about? What the hell happened? Janey takes a sip of her drink.
A prior engagement overcame me.
What?

Listen, Benjamin Hood. I have obligations that precede your... from before you showed up. One or two, you know, good-natured encounters, that doesn't mean I'm... I'm not just some toy for you. When I remembered some chores I wanted to get done before the party, I just did them, that's all, because I wanted to do them before I saw Jimmy.
Jimmy? Jimmy? I don't know how to take this. And what do you mean, Jimmy? I thought you said you and your husband --
How you take it isn't all that interesting to me, Benjamin. I'm sorry --

I just can't believe you could be so -- Stalling, he watches her take another sip of her drink an wander off. The air is filled with talk of Watergate, Billie Jean Kin the Oil Crisis, the Mets. Benjamin goes over to the couch, where Dave Gorman is chatting up an attractive younger woman.
(lighting up a joint) Welcome to the Monkey House has been a seminal influence on me -- hey Benjamin -- give it a try? This stuff will make some sense out of those larger questions.
(waving it away) Thanks for the advice Dave. But then, Benjamin changes his mind.
Uh, well, what the hey... Taking the joint, he tugs on it, holding the smoke in his lungs.
(coughing) Good shit.
Sure is good shit. It's opiated. I had it in my chamber for a while. I was smoking this other --
It's what?
Don't fret, Benjie, it's --
Darn it, Dave. He rises unsteadily, weaving through the room's conversations.

Take California. They've got their own airline in-state that's not subject to the fare controls. Compare Sacramento to L.A. on the controlled airlines and you'll see what Friedman is saying -- supply and demand, less restriction. Benjamin walks over to a window. The outdoor lamps illumi a new and heavy downpour of frozen sleet.
Paul is seated, reading the latest number of The Fantasti Four comic book. The cover displays a lurid, atomically glowing baby. The conductor walks through the cabin.
Approaching our final stop, Grand Central Station. Paul looks out the window at the tenements of Harlem, bar visible through the walls of sleet. Soon the train enters tunnel toward the station.

head_text.subj: EXT. PARK AVENUE APARTMENT BUILDING. NIGHT

text: Paul gets out of a cab and heads inside. He's met by the doorman.
Libbets Casey, please.
Your name?
Paul Hood.
(a smirk) Elevator on the right. Eighth floor -- she's waiting for you.

head_text.subj: INT. HALL IN FRONT OF LIBBETS' APARTMENT DOOR. NIGHT

text: Paul rings the bell.
(from the other side of the door) Open it Paul! Paul opens the door, and enters the apartment.
It's half dark, has an air of old wealth. Libbets skids across the parquet floor to him.
Excellent. We were waiting! She turns and runs into the den.
(under his breath) We? And there, in the den, cleaning an ounce of dope on an op copy of Nixon's Six Crises, is -- Francis.
(lifting the book up) You oughtta read this Hood, Nixon, our leader, all ye need know about the travails of life. Check out the Checkers speech stuff.
(all hope drained from him)  Francis. You gonna leave the seeds in there? In the binding like that?
All will be revealed, baby. The television is turned on to a weather report about the coming ice storm.
Awesome sleet and rain.
Major.
Howdy there. You, young knight. Can you check on the mead? Can you sally forth and secure us some more mead?
Huh?
(nasal voice, impersonating a TV character) Moisture! Moisture!
(pointing) Beer. In the pantry. Paul trudges disconsolately out of the room.
Paul, after wandering a maze of halls, enters the kitchen where he takes a six-pack out of the fridge and returns t the living room.
He enters the room with the beer.
Frankie opens them with his teeth.
(handing him a beer) Hey, it's a sellable skill. Francis licks closed a second joint, then takes the beer opens it with his rear molars.
Hell on the fillings. Paul opens the other two beers and hands one to Libbets. light up a joint.
Everything's gonna freeze, the big freeze.
Yeah, Paul, are you gonna get home okay? Paul and Francis exchange a look. She puts an Allman Brothers tape on the 8-track and turns TV down.

Wendy enters the bathroom. She fills the sink with water, then turns off the tap. Sh takes a razor blade from the counter, and slowly, determinedly, holds it to her wrist. She presses it into her skin, drawing a small drop of blo
Ouch! She drops the blade and splashes water on her wrist, grab some toilet paper and holding it against the tiny wound.
Stupid. She hears the phone ring and walks downstairs.
Wendy picks up the phone.
Hood residence.
Mikey is on the other end of the line.
You're parents at that party?
Yeah. Yours?
You get in trouble?
Maybe. Can't really tell yet.
I'm sorry if I got you into trouble. Maybe we don't have to, you know... unless you really want to.
Yeah.
I'm going to Silver Meadow, check out the ice storm... You wanna come.
Maybe.
Yeah. OK.
Mikey, bundled up in a huge orange ski parka and cap, hea for the door.
Where you going?
Out.
It's freezing.

(pausing) Yeah. When it freezes, I guess that means the molecules are not moving. So when you breathe, there's nothing in the air, you know, to breathe in to your body. The molecules have stopped. So it's clean. Sandy just looks at him. He walks out into the night.
Elena sits on a couch, talking to no one, barely looking when someone stands in front of her.
Reverend Edwards.
Perhaps you might find it in your heart to call me Philip? He sits beside her.
You're here... I'm a bit surprised.
Sometimes the shepherd needs the company of the sheep.
I'm going to try hard not to understand the implications of that simile. Philip's about to reply, but thinks better of it. They sit glumly next to each other for a minute. Then Phi rises.
Forgive me. He walks swiftly to the hall and hurriedly fishes his key out of the bowl, then heads for the door.
(passing by) I hope those weren't my keys. He laughs at his own joke as Philip rushes out the front door. Back to Elena, even more forlorn than before.
Paul enters the bathroom. We hear Francis' and Libbets' voices from the other room, laughing. He pees. At the sink, he pauses in front of the medicine cabinet, opens it.
Eureka. He pulls out some bottles.

Valium. Seconal. Uh, (can't quite pronounce this one) Par-er-goric? (a beat, looking into the mirror for effect) Francis Chamberlain Davenport the Fourth -- tonight you sleep the sleep of the just. He pockets the Seconal and turns out the light.
Paul re-enters the den to find Francis alone.
And whence has yon virginal maiden absconded?
Like into one of the other 20 or so bathrooms they've got in this place. Paul takes out the bottle and opens it.
Check it out. Not for the faint of heart.
Pharmaceutical! You are a god.

(picking up beer, trying to hurry before Libbets returns) One for you and one for me. He hands a pill to Francis, then pretends to pop one into mouth and takes a swig of his beer. As Francis downs his Paul pockets his unswallowed pill.
(in the doorway) No candy for me?
Groovy. (to Paul) Young master of the revels, a treat for our hostess?
Well, uh, I don't, it's really --
What is it?
Come on Paulie, share the wealth. You copped 'em from her mom's stash anyway.
Let's see!
(hand in pocket) Libbets, you really shouldn't mix and match, you know with the beer. I'll put 'em back. Libbets reaches into his pocket and pulls out the bottle.
Oh far out, Paulie. Hey look, these expired like five months ago. You think they're better aged? She opens up the bottle and takes one out.
Maybe you should have just a half.
Thanks for the advice dad. She takes the pill. Paul looks on, thwarted.
Ben is back at the bar, pouring another tall one. Mark Bo sidles up next to him.
Benjie, feeling no pain.
As the Indian saying goes, pain is merely an opinion.

(nodding across the room) Hey -- check it out. Maria Conrad's brought her son. (walking off) I wish some of the gang had brought their daughters! Ben feels a wave of distaste at the joke. He looks across the room as Maria and her son Neil (strin hair, acne, tie-dyed turtleneck, patched jeans) are engag Janey and Philip Edwards in conversation.

Paul, Francis, and Libbets sit on the floor, listening to music blasting at full strength. Libbets and Francis are obviously on the verge of unconsciousness. Paul regards them with a look of apprehension on his face.
Neil has now cornered Janey.
As Werner says, there is nothing to get. That's It. When you get that there's nothing to get. That's the training, when you ask yourself, the question, "What is is?"
Wait, this is the training, where they don't let you go to the bathroom?
That was the hardest part. But I did it. And you get into some far out shit.
Libbets puts a blanket over a sleeping Francis, who's cra out on the floor in a corner. Francis alternates between snores and various mumbled delirious ravings.
The foot... the foot... toeclipper man... Paul is sitting on the couch, and Libbets comes back and at his feet, facing up to him.
I guess he's just real exhausted from, you know, tests and stuff. Libbets is herself somewhat in dreamland.
Yeah.
You know Libbets, I really feel, you know, like a real connection to you --
Yeah but you don't even know me really.
Sure I do, you know, like your aura. That you give off.
My what?
It's like very positive, and I feel a real special feeling, because you really --
And I have a special feeling too, because I do. It's special.
You do? I'm glad. Because I feel for you --
And I have a feeling for you too, because you're just like -- I feel for you like you're -- you're just like --
(simultaneously) -- like a brother.
Yeah, you're not alone with that line.
I do.
Right. Cool. So, how about we take a bath together?

(consciousness fading fast) Hah hah you're funny. A bath. Like a brother and sister. Oh man, I'm so wasted. Her head bobs and weaves, her eyes close, and suddenly he head falls forward with a whoosh toward the couch -- smac dab between Paul's legs. She begins to snore instantly, her open mouth nuzzling in his crotch. Paul doesn't move, doesn't even breathe. Then, slowly, he leans his back into the couch, without shifting the rest his body. He looks as though he has simultaneously won the lottery received a lobotomy.
The crowd's a bit thinner than before. As Dot Halford begins calling out for everyone's attentio few couples make their last-minute way to the door.

OK everyone. We have a little business to attend to now. So everyone who'd like to stay, please gather in the living room. She scoops up the bowl and places it on a high end table which has been put in the middle of the room.
(walking up to Elena) Ready to go?
We're not going anywhere. Elena waves at Janey Williams, who is standing across the living room. Janey looks back without expression.
Libbets and Paul in the same position whence last we saw them. Paul delicately leans to one side of the couch and picks phone. He dials a number.
The phone rings. Wendy picks it up.
Hood residence.
(whispering) Charles, what time is it?
Is this Charles?
What time is it?
Um, ten-o-five. Why? Where are you?
I'm, uh, in the midst of a moral dilemma. And I was wondering, because I know you're a very moral person, and --
And?
Shit. I can't really talk about it. I guess I better get to the train.
Right.
What are you doing at home on a Friday night?

I have plans. Paul hangs up the phone and looks down at Libbets. Libbets' Allman Brothers tape has run out. The machine ma a repeated clicking sound as the take up real continues t circle. The only other sound is the noise of the wind and rain lashing against the apartment's windows.
