Wendy emerges from the house and gets on her bike, but th ice makes it too slippery. The storm is now in full swing She gets off and walks.
Wendy walks, barely keeping her balance in the wind.
All the couples are now gathered for the key selection process, men on one side of the room, women on the other. storm can be heard outside.
Well, what shall the order be, alphabetical? In order of appearance?
Golf handicap! Lowest handicap does the honors. Nervous laughter.
Golf handicap? Ladies, isn't it up to you?
Oh I'll go first, damn it. Let's just line up and get it over with. Maria chooses Stephen Earle. Hands the keys to him. A smattering of applause as she takes his arm and they leav
Good luck! Neil watches his mother's exit.
A few more couplings.

Helen Worthington approaches the bowl. Helen Worthington the size and shape of a sumo wrestler. There is a nervous shifting of weight on the male side of room. Helen delicately reaches into the bowl. Her hands emerge a key chain. George Clair steps forward, obviously depressed, as a collective sigh of relief goes up from behind him. Ben lo on, momentarily triumphant. Elena smiles to herself.
The Gadds choose each other.
Oh, my own husband. Isn't that against the rules?
Try again?
(relieved) Oh, I think not. Mr. Gadd smiles as they leave, obviously happy to go. Finally, only Mark Boland, Neil Conrad, Janey and Jim Williams, Rob and Dot Halford, Sari Steele, Benjamin and Elena.

Getting down to the wire! Elena steps forward. Benjamin is obviously agitated. Close on Janey's hands selecting -- away from Ben's equin key ring. She lifts up another key ring -- Neil Conrad, the teenage She hands the self-important-looking Neil his keys and th turn to go. Jim Williams smiles mysteriously to himself. Ben suddenly lurches forward, semi-drunkenly, trying to separate Neil from Janey.
(ad lib) Hey hey Ben, hang on there a sec. He backs off, ashamed, and, taking a step backwards, trip over the coffee table. Mark Boland helps lift him up.
Sorry... maybe I should... the bathroom?
Right down the hall, Ben.
(muttering) Sorry, I'm sorry. Uh, I'll be back. Dot follows Mark Boland down the hall behind Ben. Suddenly, it's just Elena and Jim Williams, and Sari Stee and Rob Halford.

(taking Sari's arm) Actually, we didn't put our keys in at all. But you won't spread it around? It's my party, and Dot isn't... hey, we're just going to slip upstairs for a while. You folks like a cup of coffee or something before we go? Elena and Jim look at each other.
Rob, we'll fix it for ourselves. You two go and get acquainted. We'll let ourselves out the front door. Jim and Elena stand there alone.
Well, I have to say I don't have much faith that my car keys are still in that bowl. Doesn't seem entirely safe, leaving your car keys around?
Let me. She takes the bowl and dips her hand in. Two sets are lef One, her own, she avoids. She takes out Jim's keys and wa across the room, handing them to him.
Thanks, but -- oh, I don't think so. It's been kind of a discouraging evening.
You couldn't have hoped for much better when you came up the walk.
Somehow it was different in my imagination when I thought about it. Actually, I didn't think about it at all, really. They sit down on the sofa.
You want coffee or something?
Well, maybe they have one of those filter jobs in the kitchen --
Look, Elena, the fact that we're neighbors... you know, close friends, well it sort of makes this a little strange, don't you think?

My husband is probably passed out in the bathroom, or at least he wishes he were. I've been married to him for 17 years and I don't have any intention of going in there to get him... so what I'm proposing is that since your wife has gone off with a boy, and since you are standing here alone, I'm proposing that you and I do what makes sense. Stay warm. Pass some time. That's all. They both look at their hands.
Now don't make me feel as if I'm being too forward, OK? If you don't
What the hey. Let's go for a drive.
Okay. Shall we clean up around here first? Do you think it's all right--

Nah, that wasn't in the contract. But they still walk around turning off lights. In the hallway, Elena looks a bit mournfully at the light seeping from underneath the bathroom door. She hears the sound of running water from inside. Then she goes into a sideroom and joins Jim. They pick up their coats.
Elena and Jim walk outside into the freezing, pelting rai Covering their faces, they jog to his car, an oversized Cadillac. A thick glaze of ice forms on his windshield.
They climb in.
We're going to have to defrost this thing for a while. He turns on the ignition, and the vents start to blow col air at them. He leans over and kisses her.

Do these seats go back? That starts it. He jumps at her, unbuckling her and unzip himself. They tangle uncomfortably for a few seconds. And then, comically, he's in her. With a groan, it's over in a flash. Jim pulls himself off, readjusting his pants.
That was awful, really awful. I'm so sorry, Elena. Elena has somehow worked herself into the cavity of the g compartment, and is trying to figure out how to extricate herself.

Things are really rotten at home. You wouldn't believe how rotten. Janey's sick. She's unstable, I guess... it's not the right time to tell you... but that's it -- it's like I can't make her happy, the boys can't make her happy, she just doesn't --
Jim, maybe we should just go. I've got to look in on the kids. Paul is supposed to be coming back in from the city.
Jesus, let me make it up to you -- I can do better than that, honestly
Well, we can talk about it.
That's fine. I wouldn't expect you to see it any other way.
Maybe you just need -- look, can you wait here a sec, I need to tidy up -- just a minute, I'll be right back. You'll wait?
Of course. She opens the door and walks back to the house.
Elena hesitantly walks to the bathroom. She opens the door. Ben's sitting on the floor, next to t toilet, woozily flipping through the pages of a magazine.
Elena.
Ben, I've got a ride home. Maybe you should sleep this one off on the couch here?
I'll drive you --
Ben. She sits on the toilet next to him, stroking his hair.
You're in no condition to drive. We'll talk in the morning, OK? He sits, accepting and quiet.
You'll get some sleep on the couch out there?
(looking up at her, with gratitude) Sure. I'll try. And we'll talk in the morning?
We'll talk in the morning.
Wendy walks up the drive in the rain, pauses, then goes t the front door and knocks lightly. The door swings ajar. pushes on it, and lets herself in.

Anyone home? Hello. Wendy wanders into the living room, then climbs the steps The sound of the wind and the darkness begin to scare her She goes into Mikey's room -- it's even more of a disaste zone than usual. She sees on the wall his dark-light poster of the 12 (sex positions of the zodiac. She notices the black garter belt on the floor, and picks up, absentmindedly swinging it in her hand as she walks o of the room. She walks back down the stairs and into the kitchen, leav the garter belt on the counter. She opens the refrigerator, grabs a jar of peanut butter, scoops some up in her finger. As she puts her finger in h mouth --
Wendy. She gives out a little yelp.
Sandy, you scared the shit out of me.
What are you doing?
Just thought I'd stop by.
Mike's out -- I think he went to Silver Meadow to see if you were hanging around there.
Yeah.
(pause) Are you his girlfriend?
No.
Elena gets in. They drive off silently.
The car moves haltingly through the sleet and ice, inches a hill, then falters and slides back silently, circling a couple of times before crashing into an embankment.
As the car slides and crashes amid Jim's and Elena's scre Silence.
You okay?
Yeah. You?
Yes. Well, I guess we can walk from here.
Jim and Elena get out, shaky, from the car. They pause for a moment. The street lamp above them sizzles, but stays on. They start to walk.

Paul and Libbets, still frozen in the same position. Fina Paul gently pushes Libbets' head back. It slides off his leg and, as Paul lurches forward in a failed attempt to grab it, Libbets flops backwards, her h hitting the carpet with a dull but decidedly loud thump.
Oh shit! Paul gets up, looks down at her. She snores. He runs over to a side table and sees the clock: 11:10.
Oh shit oh shit. He grabs his comic books and runs for the door.
The driver impassively inches down Park Avenue.
Oh shit oh shit. C'mon!

head_text.subj: INT. GRAND CENTRAL STATION PLATFORM. NIGHT

text: Paul sprints down the platform just as the doors are clos He barely makes it into the train.
Paul walks through the nearly empty train car and finds a seat. He pulls his Fantastic Four comic book out of his c pocket.
Ben makes his way to the kitchen, pours himself a cup of coffee. He sees himself reflected in the black glass of the cabin
Sandy and Wendy are sitting on the floor. He grabs his G. Joe.
Check this out. He's supposed to talk all kinds of stuff, but he's like malfunctioned. He pulls the dog tag on the doll, and G.I. Joe emits a plastic macho voice.
Mayday! Mayday! Get this message back to base!
Same thing. Again and again. Wendy takes the doll and yanks the cord.
Mayday! Mayday! Get this message back to base!

It's gonna get a lot colder tonight, I predict. Probably a blackout. Do you have candles in your house? I know where the candles are, and I have my own flashlight. Over there. Also, I know where every emergency exit is on this floor. During the course of his monologue, as Wendy looks on, Sa calmly ties a noose for his doll.
This knot's called a bowline. He puts the noose over the doll's head, as Wendy holds hi
Mayday! Mayday!
Let's hang him. Sandy drapes the noose over the edge of a dresser drawer. G.I. Joe dangles. They both look at him in silence. The silence continues.
He's dead.
If it wasn't raining we could take him outside and blow him up.
He wouldn't blow up. He'd just get all mangled or twisted. She takes him down and lays him flat on the bed. And then begins to remove his clothes. Sandy looks on, desirous.
Well. (noticing his lack of anatomy)  It looks like someone got to his private parts before us.
Communist Viet Cong.

They left it in the jungle. They speak with high seriousness. Wendy slides up on the bed where Sandy sits, a pillow on lap, and one by one, with exaggerated slowness, she remov her snowboots, as if they were stiletto heels.
Can I get into your bed?  (pause) With you? Sandy begins to shake.
We -- we have to go to the guest room. We can't stay in here. What if Mikey? My parents?
Don't worry about them. They're at that party, getting drunk and falling all over each other and making jokes about McGovern and stuff. Sandy begins to cry.
It's just -- it's just -- She takes his hand, and they walk out of the room and dow the hall, into the guest room.
Wendy and Sandy enter. She sees the vodka bottle on the dresser.
Want a drink?
Vodka?
You never tasted the stuff? She fills the glass to the brim and hands the bottle to Sandy. They clink and each toss back a sip -- Wendy almost the entire glass. Sandy coughs and gags, but swallows.
Try again. He does.
It feels warm.
One more shot?
Okay. They drink.
Under the covers. Under they go, and soon every layer of clothing emerges.
(feeling her way) Get 'em off. Sandy begins to laugh, and soon Wendy joins him. They roll around on top of each other for a while.
Have you ever had a nocturnal emission?
Huh?
That's the name for when you wake up and find this little pool of sticky stuff, like after a sexy dream. Sandy shakes his head.
They didn't tell you this stuff yet? What planet do you live on? Sandy doesn't answer, but climbs back on top of her and kisses her neck.
I love you.
That's nice. Are you drunk?
I don't know. How do I know?
I don't know either. You spin around, when you lie down. Sandy rolls off her and lies on his back.
I don't think I'm spinning. They cuddle up together. He yawns. She yawns.
Mikey walks along the edge of the empty pool in the rain. climbs up on the diving board and bounces lightly on it, then gets off and stands, looking down at the pool again.
Mikey walks across the field.

The storm has let up. Mikey walks along. With a running start, he slides on the ice down a hill. He walks back up and slides again, hollering with joy. He an image of a tiny yet absolute and positive freedom. The streetlights sputter on, then off.
Sandy and Wendy lie asleep.

A power line is down. It hisses and HUMS -- a humming ver much like the humming Mikey has been hearing earlier. The humming takes on the same transcendent tonality to wh Mikey has become so accustomed at such moments. Mikey sits down on a metal street guardrail, to ponder th sound and the snaking coil of electricity. A strange look of almost religious wonder overcomes his f as the power line connects to the guardrail.
Oh shit. Glued by an electrical pulse to the rail, he shakes as th current flows through him. After a minute, his body slumps and slides down the road.

As Paul sits reading on he moving train, the lights insid begin to sputter, and the train begins to slow. After a f moments, the train grinds to a halt, and Paul and his few fellow late night passengers are left in near total dark, with only the light of an emergency exit sign above Paul' head to light the scene. The train is eerily silent.
Ben drives home.
An emergency vehicle, lights flashing, crawls by Ben's ca He drives on slowly.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF WILLIAMS HOUSE. PRE-DAWN

text: Jim and Elena arrive on foot.
You want to come in, get a cup of coffee -- warm up? I can either walk you home, or you could crash in the guest room.
Sure. Maybe coffee.

Phone's out. I hope the pipe's -- He walks into the kitchen. The pipes have begun to burst. There's a water leak running down the walls, forming a pu on the floor. Elena has walked into the kitchen behind him. She leans against the counter, picking up the garter belt without thinking for a second, then putting it back down.
Oh well. Why don't you put on some dry socks -- and we've got some rain boots in the guest closet back there. Last room upstairs -- back of the hall. Elena climbs the stairs in her bare feet.

Elena opens the door, and discovers Wendy and Sandy aslee She stands before the bed, and gazes down on them. They look almost angelic. Wendy, sensing her presence in the room, opens her eyes, slowly coming out of sleep.

(heartbroken, softly) Get dressed. Elena walks out of the room, back to the kitchen. Wendy gets out of bed quietly, leaving Sandy sleeping peacefully. She looks at him lovingly, and tucks the blanket back up around him.
Elena and Jim are drinking coffee.
You should let him sleep. Wendy enters. She looks inquisitively at the two adults.
Where's dad?
Ben continues to drive slowly. He looks out his side wind and sees something. He puts on his brakes.

Ben gets out of the car, and stands on the top of an icy embankment. In a clump of bushes is the orange glow of a parka. He walks hesitantly toward it. Mike's body lies face down the wet ice. Ben leans down and turns the body over, then stands back amazement and saddened shock. He stands there for a moment, then picks Mike's body up, carrying him over the hill and onto the street. We see no that he is parked just a short block from the Williams's house. He bypasses his car and walks directly down the street to the house. The effort is obviously enormous. He falls fro time to time, then gets back up.
Various passengers asleep. Paul, hunched up in his seat under the faint emergency ex light, cold. He reads his comic book by the light of the emergency exit.

head_text.subj: CONTINUED TO BUILD, HE WOULD HAVE

text: Suddenly, the lights begin to flicker on and the hum of t train's engines returns. The conductor enters the car, blasting forth in his class nasal train conductor voice.
Good morning ladies and gentlemen -- On Paul, squinting in the harsh light.
The train moves slowly through a suburban, semi-forested landscape. On the street below the bridge, an emergency highway crew is removing a fallen tree, their trucks aglo flashing yellow lights.
Elena pours Wendy a cup of coffee. They're both in their coats.
I don't like coffee.
It'll warm you up. Elena sits next to her. They both raise their cups and si the coffee, not noticing the simultaneity of their moveme
Jim watches the sleeping Sandy, picks up the half-empty bottle of vodka, pours himself a drink. The noise wakes S up. Jim sits down on the bed at his feet and takes a sip.
Dad? Jim looks at him.
Elena and Wendy hear a hollering from outside, get up to what it is.
Elena and Wendy come out the front door, as Ben lays Mike body onto the ground before the front steps.
Ben? He's too breathless to speak. They stand there, looking down at Mikey. Behind Elena and Wendy, Jim appears. He pushes softly by them toward the body of his son.

Jim -- he was just up --  in Silver Lane -- I think maybe -- a power line -- Jim picks up his son. He carries him silently into the house. Sandy, now standing inside the foyer, pushes himself back against the wall as they pass, without expression. After a moment, from outside, the Hoods can hear Jim's wailing.
Do you think? Maybe we should call someone --
The phone's out.
Yeah. Well, we can just --
Ben, I don't think he wants us here. Wendy has been watching Sandy through the screen door.
Wait, I -- She turns back up the front steps and gently goes in --

on the living room floor, Jim is hugging Mike's body, his shoulders shaking uncontrollably, sobbing. Wendy walks and stands next to Sandy, who is filled momentarily with a brief inexplicable rush of anger towar her -- but she takes him and gives him an awkward, childl hug, then turns and runs out the door, joining Ben and El on the driveway. Sandy watches her go, his face wet with tears.
Oh you know, for a minute I thought it was --
Paul? Yeah. You think --
He's probably been waiting all night at the station.
C'mon.
Elena, Wendy, and Ben reach the car and get in. The car starts and drives off. There are more crews out cleaning up the storm's debris a fixing the power lines as they drive.

The train slowly pulls in. The Hood family walks down to end of the platform. The train doors open, and Paul, tired and a bit cramped, emerges. He sees his family gathered at the other end of platform, and walks to them. They stand, silent, even dignified, awaiting him. When he joins them they all walk silently to the car and in.

Sunlight floods in and temporarily blinds Ben as he start the engine. He squints, his eyes tearing a bit from the light. He looks around, first at his wife, then at his two child sitting in the back seat. He turns off the engine. Quietly, he begins to cry. He turns to the back seat.
There's something -- your mother and I -- have to tell you two -- Elena puts her hand out, almost touching him.
(softly) Ben. Paul looks at Wendy, silently asking her what's happening She casts her eyes downward, as does he.
(her hand still not yet touching him) Ben.
From above: The car, the first morning light shining upon it.
